title: i3 Z motor mount w/ Y frame connection

description.text:
This is an improved Z-motor mount I designed for my Sintron Prusa i3 acrylic to improve Z-axis rigidity. It takes the weight of the Z-motors off the frame, by directly supporting them. It also provides a more ridged connection between the XZ and Y frames.
For The right side mount just mirror the left.
I've also included a version with thin covers (0.5mm) over the motor and rod holes to support the overhangs. I haven't printed this one, but it should help with any droopy hole problems.

This is a Bench Power supply enclosure for an SFX form factor computer power supply conversion. It could be used as a project box also.
I designed it to be screwed together with common computer screws, 2.8mm pilot and 3.5mm clearance. Everything fits well and shouldn't need any cleanup, except the holes. I made a solid layer at the holes to make it more printer friendly.
Have fun with it, let me know how it goes if you make one. :)

Printer:

Anet A8

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.25mm

Infill:

10%

Notes: It may print okay without supports. I printed with supports. There is only one side model, mirror in your slicer for the opposite side. I printed with three top and bottom layers and one perimeter, Two or three would be better quality with more filament used. Mine turned out fine with one perimeter though. My bed is 220 x 220. The front and rear face plates used the whole bed. I rotated them 45 degrees for the print.

title: Liquor Bottle Cap to M10 thread adaptor

description.text:
Cap for liquorbottles with a M10 threaded rod on top. Fits somehow all bottles with 30mm cap diameter.
I tested it with several kinds of bottles, those were the ones that fit:
  • Johnny Walker
  • Barcardi
  • Havanna Club
  • Captain Morgan
    • Bottles that did not fit:
  • 360 Wodka
  • Jim Beam
  • Barcardi Oakheart
    • Nope, I´m not an alcoholic I just collect bottles :D I will upload a second version that also fits the bottles with a wider thread soon as well as a customizeable version to adjust the size of the threaded rod on top.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

50%

Notes: The cylinder in the center functions as support and as a stabilization for the threaded rod on top. So no additional support is required
I designed this to build a lamp from an IKEA lamp socket an a liquor bottle as the pictures show but I guess there will be several more intersting applications for this

comments.text: prints and fits wine bottles no problem - could do with one for liqueur bottles :)

description.text: "Hackesí - Hack the System" is a 3D printed collaborative board game with 70 pieces designed to promote the Hacker Ethic playing to different game versions that people design in a collaborative way. Update: At last I need to work a little more to have ready the Hackesi website translation to English but by now I've got the Spanish version https://www.hackesi.cc/es I hope to finish the English translation to March and to get a better Internet connection to the servers of our hacktivist collective.

I designed Hackesí looking at the hacker emblem called Glider, and how similar looks to the known game "dominoes". So I studied how could I create the pieces needed to people could collaborate creating their own game versions, like the Copyleft software, with their own rules with this pieces, leaving the competitive point of view out.

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:148722 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=148722

Using the following options: word = MakerStation
font_scale = 2.1

inner_length = 125
font_spacing = 0.81
tolerance = 0.2
lid_length = 30
tip_diameter = 4
pen_thickness = 7
helper_tabs = 0

This is a Hairy Lion. As the name says it is lion with hair.
This is a remix from Geoffro's design Lion HD (no supports required). UPDATE #2: I made about 3 times bigger version. It has a lot of hair and they are also very long.
Watch Joel Telling's (3D Printing Nerd) video about it: https://youtu.be/OTXPU2P-ElE UPDATE #1: I made 50% smaller version. It should only take about 1-2 hours to print. But you must be much more careful when cutting the hair. This model has much less hair, so if you break or pull out too much hair, there will be visible bald spots. The hair is connected to sacrificial wall, which is removed afterwards.
(See picture: post_processing.jpg) You can also try hot water to form the hair. Anyway, be careful not to burn yourself. There was a request to add a brim to sacrificial wall. So I made it: "Hairy_Lion_with_brim.STL" This was printed with ABS, but it should also work with other materials. If you are having problems, adjust bridging settings in your slicer. You can find dual extrusion version here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2050208

Printer:

Renkforce RF1000

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

15%

Notes: This is only for 0.2 mm layer height.

comments.author: hugoarchicad

comments.text:
Sorry, I really don't have time to do any more hairy objects.
But I can tell you how it is done and you can do it yourself:
Open/Import your model in your software. Make one hair: rectangular sketch and extrude for desired layer height (for example 0.2 mm). Then decide what kind of pattern you want. It depends on shape of a model and on desired direction of hair "growth". I used circular pattern, but you can also use linear or curve pattern. When making circular pattern be aware that in the middle hair will join together (You can see that on very top of hairy lion - it looks like a small disc). Then you also have to pattern it vertically. You could just use linear pattern, but I prefer curve pattern on helix. That way hair seems to be more natural and you don't get vertical bald spaces with no hair. The best would be random placement, but I didn't know how to make that. Vertical space between hair was 1mm in my case, so the hair don't join together with hair below and above. Now you have to cut and remove the hair where you don't want it: on the face, neck, ears,...
And then you build a wall and combine it all together. I didn't combine/merge the hair with main body until the end, because otherwise it is hard to remove unwanted hair. At least with CAD software, maybe it is different if you use mesh software.
comments.author: hugoarchicad

comments.text:
In theory it is very simple: You make one hair - just long and thin rectangular cuboid. Then you make a pattern (linear, circular, on a curve) and then also a pattern in 3rd dimension (linear, on a curve). Then you just have to cut out hair on the parts where you don't want hair.
In reality it can get a bit complicated. Generating a lot of hair can take a while and basically all operations with hair can take a while to complete. You can also run into different bugs, errors and crashes.
I made this model in Solidworks, You could make it also in Fusion360 or any other CAD program.
comments.author: phil123456

comments.text: I'd then recomend using blender, the particle system is really handy when it's about creating hair specifying on wich faces you want to generate on the mesh... you can also paint objects on mesh faces with some plugins

comments.text: Would blowing back the hair work with a hair dryer on high heat?
comments.author: DMC3d_and_more

comments.text:
I don't know. I don't use a hair dryer, so I don't know how hot it gets. I think it should work for PLA. Try it on some thin PLA piece that you don't need (from purging the nozzle or from skirt) and see if it softens.
Another option I heard it works is hot water. I imagine you boil some water and dunk the lion head in. Then pull it out and form the hair before it cools down. Or you could just quickly move it around in a water, so the water resistance forms the hair.
But be careful and don't splash yourself with boiling water.
comments.author: DMC3d_and_more

comments.text: I tried with a hair dryer, but the one I used didn't create enough heat to make PLA soft. Boiling water is probably hotter than you need. Try with some lower temperature to reduce the risk for burns.

comments.text:
It is not really meant to be scaled down. Currently hair have thickness of 0.6mm and height of 0.2mm. If you scale it down for 50% that gets you thickness of 0.3mm and height of 0.1mm. This might be hard for slicer to detect. Also thickness of sacrificial wall changes from 0.6 to 0.3mm.
Maybe if you are trying to make a small one try printing it with 0.1mm layer height (and maybe play with detect thin walls settings in slicer)?

comments.text:
This is cool. I enjoy alternative 3d printing methods and uses.
Also I kinda like the pre-processed round lion mane. I think he'd make a fun pipe brush or dish scrubber if done in a more robust plastic like nylon or PET.
Great job.
comments.author: cyclone

comments.text:
Thanks.
You really need to have good settings to ensure good bonding between hair and core base. Sometimes they are attached only by very tiny strand. But something like nylon might work.
I haven't really thought about any practical use of this, for me it was just something interesting I can do with a 3d printer. Making custom size brushes for hard to reach places or odd sized pipes would be a really good practical use.

description.text:
This is a simple filament spool insert to allow a spool to spin on a M8 (or similarly sized) threaded rod. The legs are designed to bend a bit when inserted into the spool to allow for a snug fit. It was designed to fit into a spool with about a 75 mm diameter opening. Print two of these for each side of the spool. Only about 20 mm of the hole is touching the threaded rod which reduces friction and allows the spool to spin freely.
SCALE UP BY A FACTOR OF 10 BEFORE PRINTING

0.3mm

5%-10% (depending on desired rigidity)

description.text:
Mein erstes Ding mit NinjaFlex... Den Foxeer BOX Rubber Suit hat es hier… Den GoPro Session Rubber Suit hat es hier… Den RunCam 3 Rubber Suit hat es hier… Musste nun endlich mal meine Runcam HD2 richtig schützen, darum habe ich mir mal ein Muster NinjaFlex bestellt. Dank ein bisschen Internet Recherche, hat‘s gleich beim ersten Mal ohne Probleme funktioniert. Die Kamerahalterung sollte schon mit Flexiblem Filament gedruckt werden, da diese recht eng anliegt. Die Stützen hab ich schon mit PLA, ABS und PET gedruckt, ist also egal. Die Stützen sind ziemlich Crash resistent und sollten auf alle Fälle mit einem Kabelbinder zusätzlich am Frame gesichert werden. Ich hab mal drei Typen mit 25° und 30° hochgeladen,
  • ZMR250
  • QAV220 (Lochabstand 28x45)
  • QAV190 (Lochabstand 34x43).
    • Falls wirklich jemand Interesse hat, sind die Stützen schnell auf andere Frames angepasst. Ulimaker 2+ und NinjaFlex:
  • Nozzle Temp. 233°
  • Bed Temp. 40° (3DLAC, Hairspray No.5)
  • Speed 20-25mm/s (zu schnell bringt nur Probleme)
  • Fan speed 50% ab Layer 3
  • No retraction !!!

title: 1x2x3 Puzzle Zee
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is an easy to assemble and turn 1x2x3 rotating Rubik style Puzzle Zee that allows you to create an interactive piece of art!  
When the remix challenge was announced, I looked through the Remix Challenge Collection for inspiration on something to create.  I liked the Zee Blank because it reminded me of a bear sculpture series I saw at the Henry Doorly Zoo in Omaha.  The sculptures are all the same shape and each is painted differently expressing each artists creative vision for the bear.  I figured that I would bring it to the next level by mixing it with another item from the Remix Challenge Collection, the Ozo 1x2x3 puzzle bear making it an interactive piece of art!  So, I imported the Zee Blank into Tinkercad and started slicing and dicing.
I knew that I couldn't just post pictures of a blank one since the whole point of the Zee Blank is to use it as a canvas for creative expression.  So I looked again at the Remix Challenge Collection for inspiration and decided to base it on the excellent Bearded Yell sculpture.  For additional detail, I drew Beefy Arms (as beefy as I could for a Zee) and had him hold the Baby's First Mace.  
Behold the Beefy armed bearded yell with his battle mace.  Or maybe yelling to his baby that he found her mace :)

Supports:

Yes

Notes: I printed this with two shells and 5% infill. I did not use support on mine and there was a very small amount of droop on the feet that cleaned up easily. I would recommend using support on the feet due to their overhang, but in my case it was not necessary. Also note that on my print the edges started to pull up a little. That is why you see a little crack where the pieces meet. I recommend a brim or other means to ensure that the edges don't lift.

comments.text: The head and feet are held to the center body by the round protrusion being captured in the slots in the body sections.  The two body sections are held together by the pin connector.  This allows the head and feet to be rotated and if all three vertical sections are lined up, it can be rotated vertically as well.

remixed_from.author: jbeale
remixed_from.title: Raspberry Pi Camera Objective Lens Adaptor

description.text:
With reference to Jbeale's original idea:
I just changed the internal barrel id up to 25.4mm which then slides nicely over the microscope tube. I've added the STL file but it's easy enough to start with jbeale's original openscad file. This particular budget microscope only has a sub-stage plano/concave mirror so I've used a torch to illuminate the (blood smear) slide. I think you will get improved pictures in natural daylight or by using proper illumination. Note I've removed the original pi camera lens and I'm not using the microscope's eye piece lens. Also Jbeale's idea is for camera v2. Camera v1 has some additional surface mounted chips so you just need carve a pocket into the mating face. use
raspivid -k -o dummypreview
while focusing and to take a picture:
raspistill -o .jpg There are tons of settings to play with on the Pi Camera
and you could even do some time lapse filming. https://www.raspberrypi.org/documentation/raspbian/applications/camera.md Revision 0: I've added a PI zero mounting plate. Use 4 standoff's to connect to the pi zero. This also keeps the ribbon connector tidy. The mounting plate rebate is now designed for v1 and v2 Pi cameras. An objective sleeve that fits the larger dia 25.4mm barrel so you can mount the objective as per JBeales's telephoto lens. Slide the sleeve into barrel and clamp up the objective when the image comes into sharp focus. I've supplied the openscad files because your objective may have different dimensions. Learn more about microscopes: http://www.microscopy-uk.org.uk/

author: bermuda

title: FrSky XM and XM Plus Receiver Cases

description.text:
Cases for the FrSky XM and XM Plus receivers to provide a little more protection than the clear shrink-wrap that is installed from the factory. This is a simple two piece case which allows access to the BIND button and connections. I'm using the XM with my RX2SIM to allow wireless simulation/practice with my Horus. Files have been updated to support the 90 degree header connector. I don't have an XM Plus, so I haven't verified the fit to an actual receiver.
I have made one final edit on the XM Plus case based on feedback and now feel it is finished.

Printer:

Original Prusa i3 MK2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.15mm

Infill:

N/A

Notes: Print in a transparent/translucent material to be able to see the status LEDs inside. I used a clear PETG+. Side walls are 0.9mm thick assuming an extrusion width of 0.45mm (0.4mm nozzle). Best printed when laying flat on the print bed, not the orientation as it comes out of Fusion 360. Supports are optional for the connector window.

It will require a couple of spots of CA adhesive to attach the lid to the body.  Also, the antenna end of the lid will require a little sanding for the lid to fit the body flush as the height of the end wall is determined by the printer's layer resolution/accuracy.

remixed_from.author: marciot
remixed_from.title: NRG Energy (San Diego) Server Cabinet Blanking Panels

title: Renewable Energy Demonstration Raspberry Pi Cabinet

description.text:
I have remixed the NRG Energy (San Diego) Server Cabinet Blanking Panels concept.
My remix is an interactive Renewable Energy demonstration Raspberry Pi (RPI) case with a process diagram about the wind solar hybrid electricity generation. It contains a lot of recycled element. This design has a fully functional and adjustable (reversed direction to use like a fan) wind turbine, and photovoltaic cell which can recharge the power bank. It has also a red LED on the top of the wind turbine which is blinking and an other blue LED which operates as a street lamp. Both of them are programable from the RPI. The RPI can be used as a server and in this case it is a server cabinet. You can customize this case with your own side walls. Watch my short demonstration video:
https://youtu.be/2rNdK6mnyPs

Notes: Walls:
Infill: 100%
Layer hight 0.1mm The smaller side walls are made with the so called Lithophane technology. You can make your own picture with the help of this app from this site:
http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run? The front panel diagram is made in Solidworks.
If you have a 0.2mm nozzle than I could recommend to use it for the best quaility. Base:
Infill: 30%
Layer hight 0.2mm
IMPORTANT:
Do not let the slicer to make support material inside the cable tubes from the lamp and the wind turbine. The long rectengular shape in the middle could get support because it is easy to take off.
The Base part should get around 100°C (I used PLA) or even higher bed temperature to avoid the Warping effect. Turbine blade:
Infill: 100%
Layer hight 0.1mm Lamp + Lamp cap, Turbine parts, Display Frame:
Infill: 100%
Layer hight: 0.2mm

The hardest to design geometry from the model is the wind turbine blade.
I used these instructions to make my own blade profile. http://blogs.solidworks.com/tech/2015/08/create-wind-turbine-blade-using-surface-lofts.html You can find profiles from here:
http://wind.nrel.gov/airfoils/shapes/S809_Shape.html I also made an adjustable angle turbine blade concept, check it out. RPI sizes:
https://www.raspberrypi.org/documentation/hardware/raspberrypi/mechanical/RPI-3B-V1_2.pdf

For your own side walls the recomended picture sizes:
88mm x 54mm x 0.8mm base plate and 78mm x 50mm picture area (5mm frame at the sides and 2mm from the top and bottum) which has normaly 2mm additional thickness but it is up to you. Costumizable side picture recommended sizes

I have built in a reset switch for the RPI to make it more confortable.
It has a slide switch for the wind turbine.
Every cable runs inside the modell so be carefull how do you print it out. (see the print settings).
For the LED-s I used 220 ohm resistors between the RPI GPIO pins and the LEDs.
For the Reset button, you need to connect it to the RUN pins, that are located on the board. You need to solder some connector pins on it if you do not want to solder the cables directly to the board. Street Lamp wiring:
The positive side of the LED is connected to the GPIO17 pin (which is notionally the first user GPIO pin. It’s physical location is pin 11 on the GPIO connector), the negative side is connected to one of the ground pins. (pin 9 is handy for this purpose) Lamp LED wire path Reset button wire path USB to slide Switch to DC-DC converter wire path DC-DC converter out to DC-motor wire path (The red LED is going through in the same way just it is connected to the RPI) Wire connections: reset switch (Blue, White), Red LED (Red. White), Blue LED (Green, White), Cooling fan (Red, Black)

The red LED on the top of the wind turbine is connected as an ACT LED on the RPI so it is always flashing when the RPI working.
To set up this, you need to add the following line to /boot/config.txt
You can type into the terminal that: sudo nano /boot/config.txt Than add: (I used it on GPIO26) dtoverlay=pi3-act-led,gpio=26 ctr +x,
y
Enter
After reboot, it should work. Street Lamp setup:
In terminal simply type:
gpio mode 0 out (this means that we set up the pin for output)
gpio write 0 1 (here we turn it on) if you want to turn it off you can type:
gpio write 0 0 If you want to write a program for this you can follow the instructions from this link:
https://thepihut.com/blogs/raspberry-pi-tutorials/27968772-turning-on-an-led-with-your-raspberry-pis-gpio-pins

I used a lot of recycled parts but I searched on the internet some similiar ones which are fit to my modell.
My DC motor and slide switch is from a broken RC helicopter,
The cables and LED-s are from an old PC case that somebody thrown out.
The cooling fan is from an old graphic card. Display:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dr9YGyOCWbM DC motor:
http://www.ebay.de/itm/3-7V-25000RPM-18-x-12-x-10mm-Body-Micro-DC-Motor-for-Airplane-Model-/192057583914?hash=item2cb786292a:g:t4sAAOSwZQRYV~gA DC-DC Converter:
http://www.ebay.de/itm/301588715679?_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2648&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT LED-s:
http://www.ebay.de/itm/Transparente-High-Quality-LEDs-Leucht-Dioden-in-verschiedenen-Grosen-und-Farben-/171370401875?var=&hash=item27e678d053:m:myDHtgaZcdvr4vHanhSXiCA Switch button:
http://www.ebay.de/itm/10pcs-SS12F44G4-1P2T-3-Pin-DIP-2-Position-SPDT-Vertical-Slide-Switch-for-PCB-/262234663122?hash=item3d0e6768d2:g:Z5oAAOSwT6pVkQP6 Reset button:
http://www.ebay.de/itm/10pcs-8-5-x-8-5mm-x-18mm-Momentary-Tactile-Tact-Push-Button-Switch-DIP-Black-Cap-/291580828727?hash=item43e3925c37:g:IAUAAOSwdvpWENhQ PowerBank:
http://www.ebay.de/itm/222312659492?_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2648&var=521156094361&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT Fan is from this board, but it is better if you search for a 5V small fan it has enough space to built in up to 60mm fans:
https://www.asus.com/Graphics-Cards/EN7300GSHTD_Series/ Keyboard:
http://www.ebay.de/itm/Rii-Mini-K12-Bluetooth-3-0-Tastatur-mit-Touchpad-aus-Metall-Retoure-/332075562031?hash=item4d513ef42f:g:mk4AAOSw44BYZOLt

title: PTFE Tube Adapter for Printrbot Aluminum Extruder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I have a printrbot simple (2013 V1 heavily modified) that's still chugging along. The one
problem that has bugged me about this style of printer is that the cantelever design
causes horizontal lines along vertical walls when the Y-axis pulls against
a filament spool. For the longest time I thought this was related to an issue with the acme rod being off
center, but eventually realized that my acme rod is properly centered and the problem
was really just spool drag along the Y-axis I fixed the problem by running the filament through a PTFE tube which is anchored
at the extruder and at the spool, eliminating the Y-axis pull on the filament and the
resulting annoying horizontal lines. The extruder end just snaps on the lever at the top of the extruder. The spool end is
designed to ride on a wire coat hanger which sits in front of the spool - see the
pictures. This mod did exactly what I had hoped it would. The horizontal lines along vertical
walls are gone. I went with this design instead of just switching to a Bowden extruder because I like
having the ability to print with flexible filament, and you really can't consistently
push ninjaflex through a tube, but you can certainly pull it through one.

Printer:

Printrbot Simple 2013 V1 (heavily modified)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

25%

Once printed, screw the brass fitting into the printed part. The hole on the part isn't threaded,
but it's sized so the brass fitting will cut it's own threads without much effort.

description.text:
I rebuilt the clamp and screw for the "Universal HTC Vive Desk Mount" because i wasn't able to print them without fusing together, which resulted in a screw that wouldn't turn.
These parts are now all separated, so after printing them you just have to insert the screw and then screw the cap onto the end. It's quite a tight fit, but that also means it won't unscrew by itself.

author: nalby

description.text: Accurate and to scale recreation of a Sega Genesis / Megadrive.

After circulating this game around my office, there were a few common traits about these pieces that confused people. The first was the shape of the pieces when they were hollow; the hole is always circular, leading people to think that meant the shape itself was round even when it was square. And the last was that people kept playing the pieces upside-down without realizing it (since there was no hole on the bottom of hollow pieces, it would affect the game).
My solution here was to match the shape of the hollow hole with the shape of the piece and to make them symmetrical so there was no top and bottom distinction, you can play them any orientation without confusion.

title: K'Nex adapters for Arduino and electronic hardware

description.text:
---- This project is in developpement ---
Please see the Github project's page: https://github.com/MxBoud/ardublocklyForKNexRobot ---Description of parts---
--MotorToKNex.stl--
This part is a bracket to mount the Kuman stepper motor (http://kumantech.com/kuman-stepper-motor-for-arduino-5-sets-28byj-48-uln2003-5v-stepper-motor-uln2003-driver-board-dupont-40pin-male-to-female-jumper-ribbon-cable-k67_p0057.html). Fixation is done with a M3 screw. --MotorDriverToKNex.stl--
This part is for mounting the Kuman stepper motor drive (http://kumantech.com/kuman-stepper-motor-for-arduino-5-sets-28byj-48-uln2003-5v-stepper-motor-uln2003-driver-board-dupont-40pin-male-to-female-jumper-ribbon-cable-k67_p0057.html) on a K'Nex base. Fixation is done with four M3 screws. --SonarToKNex.stl--
This is a K'Nex connector for a ultrasonic ranger (http://kumantech.com/kuman-5pcs-hc-sr04-ultrasonic-distance-measuring-sensor-module-kit-for-arduino-uno-mega-r3-mega2560-duemilanove-nano-raspberry-pi-brobot-k18_p0033.html). Fixation is done with a M3 screw. --ArduinoMegaUnoToKNex.stl--
This is a mount for an Arduino Uno or Mega board (holes can adapt to both types of boards). Fixation is done with some M3 screws. --MotorShaftToKNex--
By printing two pieces of this part, the stepper motor shaft can be extended to attach a K'Nex rod on it. This part needs some improvements because it seems not strong enough. Fixation is done with six M3 screws.

comments.text: I also found out while experimenting with k'nex and arduino you can take apart the official k'nex motor, take out the switch, and connect that to a motor driver to make it a simple controllable dc k'nex motor.
comments.author: lmg1114

This is another Dual-Z-Axis-Mod for the Vellemann K8200.
You need to find another location for your Z-Limit-Switch, I use an inductive sensor near my Hotend.
You'll get about 50 mm more Z-Height.

Printer:

K8200

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2mm

25%

You need to buy these Parts: 1 x Stepper NEMA17 (e.G. Wantai 42BYGHW811)
2 x TR8x1.5 400 mm Trapezoidal thread spindles
2 x Trapezoidal nut 20Ø x 16
4 x 626ZZ Bearings
2 x Flex-Coupler 5mm / 5mm
2 x Linear shafts 10 x 345 4 x Screw M5 x 25 (Z-Axis_Guides.stl to Z-Nut_Part2.stl)
4 x Washer M5 x 10 (Z-Axis_Guides.stl to Z-Nut_Part2.stl) 8 x Screw M4 x 16 (Z-Nut_Part2.stl and Z-Nut_Part1.stl)
8 x Nut M4 (Z-Nut_Part2.stl and Z-Nut_Part1.stl) 6 x Screw M5 x 10 (Z-Motor_Support.stl and 626ZZ_Bearing_Support.stl to Frame)
6 x Washer M5 x 10 (Z-Motor_Support.stl and 626ZZ_Bearing_Support.stl to Frame)
6 x Nut M5 Squared (Z-Motor_Support.stl and 626ZZ_Bearing_Support.stl to Frame) 8 x Screw M3 x 8 (Z-Motor_Support.stl to Motor)
8 x Washer M3 x 7 (Z-Motor_Support.stl to Motor) 4 x Screw M5 x 30 (10mm_Rod_support.stl to Frame)
4 x Washer M5 x 10 (10mm_Rod_support.stl to Frame)
4 x Nut M5 Squared (10mm_Rod_support.stl to Frame) Instructions You need to print all STL files twice. The TR-Nut fits perfectly inside the (blue) Nut-Support-Shells. When the nut slips, you can drill through the existing hole in the top-shell and cut a thread into the nut. There you can put a screw in for fixing. You need to machine the ends of the thread bars, as shown in the drawing "Trap_mach.pdf". This requires a lathe or a good friend with a lathe. Mount the Extruder-Plate on the Top-Side of the Z-Arm. title: Square Peg and Hole Fitment Test

description.text:
A test print to help you figure out how much clearance you need for two printed parts to fit into each other. The main peg is a 5mm x 5mm cube. The peg board has holes of the following dimensions: 4.8mm x 4.8mm
4.9mm x 4.9mm
â€¦
5.8mm x 5.8mm In my print, the 5.1mm x 5.1mm slot ( 0.05mm clearance per side) gave a good and very tight fit - perhaps for permanent connections. The 5.2mm x 5.2mm square (0.1mm clearance per side) gave a good generally-useful fit.

title: Keyblade of the People's Hearts - Kingdom Hearts

description.text:
Watch here: https://youtu.be/5HKrSMN4r2M It's the last day of #3DPrintmas! And we're ending it with a bang. It's a full sized Keyblade Prop from the game Kingdom Hearts. This is Riku's Keyblade when he turns into Riku Ansem. Also called the Keyblade of People's Hearts. I created the model in Fusion 360 by tracing a sketch and revolving the blade part. Then extruded the spiky bits at the top and the handle guards. I also created pins to hold the different pieces together and I labeled the inside of each piece so it's easier to tell where things go to assemble it. Then my wife glued all the pieces together. Used repair putty to fill the seams. She sanded the crap out of it and sprayed with a few coats of filler primer. Then she painted it with some hammered metal and some black spray paint (Red for the handle guards). Then hand painted the purple and gold parts around the handle. Print Settings:
Printer: Da Vinci 1.0 Pro
Filament: Hatchbox PLA
Layer Height: 0.3mm
Infill: 20%
Supports: No
Raft: No

author: qpidgiga

description.text: Just a simple coat hook that hangs off a door.

After using Prusa i4 for a while now and following closely the small problems people face, I must say it is a well designed Printer – especially for beginners. However, Prusa i4 has one major issue. The control board heats up. Most of us add fans to cool the board.
I discovered 2 issues with the i4 design that are easy to solve.
1) The control board Heating up
2) Some challenges to maintain print quality especially if you are printing a temperature sensitive material such as ABS.
Fortunately, both issues are solved with one solution. If you check below the hotbed, the power supply unit is equipped with a cooling fan (its speed changes with the heat level). Above the power supply unit, there is the acrylic cover and the rest is covered by the hot bed! PROBLEM! This means the heat from the power supply unit can’t escape the base unit. All the heat from the power supply is actually distributed within the base affecting the control board!
The second effect of this design is that the hot air is blown partly to the table and onto your print! Hence affect your printing quality to a small degree (trust me, if you do the mod suggested here, you will notice a difference and you will be 100% in control of your settings, no external factors to affect them).
The solution is to take the power supply fan out, mount it on top of the base (still connected to the power supply original connection point) and provide chimney to direct the air away from the table...and of cause, you need to cut the acrylic cover to allow for smooth air flow – use a dremel, simple. I believe the pictures below are self explanatory. You will need to remove the fan connector plastic using a pin (figure it out) and return it back once the wires pass through the base.

remixed_from.author: Thomasdc_
remixed_from.title: The geometric stand for MacBook Pro Retina

title: The Geometric Adjustable Laptop+ Stand
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Intro
This is a remix of Thomasdc_'s thing "The geometric stand for MacBook Pro Retina" for the Thingiverse remix challenge. I was inspired by the ergonomic design of stand but wanted to make a more versatile design while keeping with the geometric theme. Prints/parts required
4x axle.stl
4x endcap.stl (I didn't find that they were necessary, but they are more permanent)
2x base.stl
2x arm.stl
2x support ^ ^ two of any file, _small = 11mm vertical gap, _medium = 16mm vertical gap and _large = 22mm vertical gap. Use _upright if your printer has a large vertical print area (ex. a delta printer) and _side if your printer has a large print surface in the x or y axis (ex. a cartesian based printer) Video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qPuTsGzAU04

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

RepRap Kossel

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

100 - 300 microns

Infill:

30% or more for strength

Notes: Supports could be used to increase print quality in some areas, however I didn't find that they were necessary. Additionally, a raft could be used to increase adhesion on some prints, but this did not seem necessary either.

Required parts for one stand section (2 are required) Take the base piece, support and an axle, arranging them as shown, pushing the axle through Grab another axle and the arm piece, pushing the axle through each piece Once completed move the arm from each notch to change the angle Note: end caps The four end caps (endcap.stl) can also be added were there is exposed axle to finish the stand further, although I did not find this to be necessary. Depending on your print accuracy you may need to scale the end caps between 98% - 102%.

To start I simply striped away the geometric design and base of the larger stand piece leaving only the support for the laptop. Next, I took a measurement of the length of the support( ≈ 140mm) and then calculated how far apart the notches on the base needed to be to give angles of 45°, 40°, 35°, 30°, 25°, 20° and 15°. This was calculated through the sine law were x/sin(a) = y/sin(b) = z/sin(c). In this case x ≈ 70mm and y = x(√2). By subbing in the required angle, length z could be solved for. Once each z length was calculated the base was modelled with the appropriately distanced notches for each angle. Then, I created two other sizes of support bracket for different sized laptops, devices or objects. Lastly, the arm was modelled and holes were put in place to create hinges so the parts could move properly.

author: Plasticore

description.text:
Quick and dirty code with few protections.
Print in vase mode with some not to brittle plastic
Don't go crazy with radius and stick to steps even divisible to height. As usually i appreciate reports of successful prints especially in flex type materials . x = 25; // bellows inner measurement
y = 50; // bellows inner measurement
approx_z = 100; // bellows relaxed height without sleeves
steps = 10; // number of folds
step = round(aprox_z / steps);
z=step*steps; // exact height ext = 1.5; // fold horizontal extension multipler
radi = 1; //
verticalsegment = 0.2; // vertical segment between folds
sleeve = 20; // Sleeve at ends
sleeve_ext = 0; // Sleeve horizontal extension (multiplied by sleeve value added to x/y) Huge thanks to Elstak for Verification and this nice video https://youtu.be/jIlPBB8f2_I
https://openscadsnippetpad.blogspot.com/

Thank you for the feedback.
You have to cut away that bottom side with Scissors or maybe tin-snips. Shouldn't be too hard. The bellows is intended to be printed as just perimeters with no infill (vase mode). A U shaped surface is not closed and would not make sense to the 3D printer. So its a bit wasteful on material but there is unfortunately no easy way around it with this code base.
You're very welcome to share pictures of successful prints in use.
Good luck.

This is a die for determining the outcome of the Magic: the Gathering card 'Mana Crypt'. If you're unfamiliar with the card, you can see it here: http://gatherer.wizards.com/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?multiverseid=184773 Basically, the outcome is going to be either "lose 0 life" or "lose 3 life", hence half the faces represent one of each of those two values. In the pictures above, the die is printed in ColorFabb Bronzefill. I think this really adds the weight that you want in a die and it feels great in your hand. Next steps will be weathering it to make it look cool in the way that only metal-fused filaments can.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes: I oriented the faces such that you shouldn't need any support inside the numbers and you shouldn't need to make any changes to the print orientation. If you don't have decent cooling, you may get some drooping on the top of the numbers.

Is this a "fair" die? A "fair" die is one that's perfectly balanced/weighted such that the rolls are completely random and not affected by the makeup of the die itself. I honestly did zero work to determine if this is a truly fair die or not. The volume missing from the 3's and 0's is pretty similar, but I'm sure one creates a slightly larger (though likely insignificant) negative space than the other. Beyond that, given that different printers will design and orient infill differently, it's impossible to create one file that will produce a "fair" die on each and every printer across all settings. I would be surprised if this produces a greatly skewed result one way or another, but if anyone wants to document any bias based on thousands of rolls against a particular set of print settings, I'd be interested in knowing the results. The reality is that most dice are not truly fair -- even ones produced by some of the most popular and prolific manufacturers that we purchase from today. I think most people get hung up on printed dice because they feel it's easier for someone to willfully cheat even though that likelihood is going to be extremely small.

comments.text: on the type of magnet question, it's to prevent there from being polarity problems.  with a magnet stuck in in one direction, it can be really easy to make a mistake and then your tiles repel one another.  With spherical magnets, they are free floating and can turn, preventing any polarity problems from happening.

comments.text: I've considered it, but the design for a door isn't trivial. The problem is that when you print it, you get some overhang, and how much that overhang droops varies a lot between printers. Getting it to work consistently is something of a bear. If I was going to go for the pocket, it would probably be splitting the tile at the very top of the openlock port so that it can be sandwiched, thus avoiding overhang issues.

title: Prusa i3 MKII Spool Coaster Tray

description.text:
I wanted a better solution to the spool mount on the Prusa i3 MKII. The Spool Coaster offered by Printrbot provides near frictionless spool rotation. This tray holds the Spool Coaster and discharges the filament just above the extruder.
The holes in the tray are clearance for 3x10mm screws. The holes in the mounts are sized so screwing in a 3mm screw (metal) will cut threads. 
Fabricated using Atomic Filament Gun Metal Gray PLA at 210C, bed at 55C. Wall thickness 2mm all around, 15% infill.

title: Ultimaker 1 & 2 Print Table Stabilizer (Anti-Oscillation)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Update 1/18/17
This method that you are looking at right now worked great. I would say it took care of bout 75% of my oscillations. I purchased an anti-backlash nut and when I installed it, I had to tear a lot of things apart. I decided to make a more permanent solution. I went to the hardware sore to see what they had that I could bolt on the bottom of my print table. I found this aluminum 1/2" x 1/2" channel used for trim on 3/8" plywood. The shape of it makes it very rigid and it's the smallest thing I could find. I didn't want to be tearing apart my printer again any time soon so I I cut two lengths to be bolted using existing holes. The same holes that my first system used. This combined with my anti-backlash nut & adapter has almost completely taken care of the oscillations and vibrations. I would say 90-95%! Not an exaggeration. My first system is not as invasive and could have possibly eliminated more of the vibrations if I tweaked it, so I won't remove it from my designs. I have attached a couple pictures of the channel I bolted on the bottom of the print table and a picture of the manufacturers sticker. You could actually utilize both systems if you want but I'm getting great results with the channel and backlash nut. I built Jason's awesome UM2 Aluminum Extrusion Clone with the genuine UM0 heated bed upgrade kit and I noticed some vibration / oscillation on the end of the print table. I know for a fact this causes problems with prints. After installation I noticed a huge decrease in the amount of visible vibrations. I can still see some but this is a WIP and this is a big step in the right direction. My next step is to add an anti-backlash nut to the Tr8 leadscrew. I wouldn't be sharing this if it didn't make a difference. I don't know if this is a problem for all Ultimaker printers using the same print bed but I do know it's an issue for some. This is very easy to print and uses minimal hardware. I designed it around 5mm threaded rod because I had it on hand after converting my Prusa i3 Clone to leadscrews. There isn't a lot of room between the heated plate and the support plate but this fits with a small clearance when the bed adjustment screws are tightened all the way. I also designed this to utilize existing holes / hardware from the print bed. I was not looking to pull up or down on the front of the print table. I am just trying to keep it in one spot, add rigidity. The STL files are arranged properly for printing with layer orientation and strength in mind. I may add an identical set of these supports on the bottom of the print table. This will work with the original wood back cover but you would have to make two cuts for the threaded rod to pass under or you could install this on the bottom side of the table but without support on the top, I'm not sure how much this would help. I do have a back cover designed for the table that will allow use of this support without modification. This system helps tremendously but does not completely do away with vibrations. The difference is very noticeable HARDWARE
(2) 5mm threaded rods @ 260mm apx.
(8) M5 Nuts
(4) 16mm M3 bolts (longer bolts to pass through brass leadscrew nut)
(6) M3 Nuts (4-leadscrew nut / 2-front bed support)
(2) 6mm M3 bolts for the top of the suuport "sandwich" around the leadscrew nut
(8) Zip Ties - small size

UM2 Aluminum Clone

Resolution:

.2 or smaller

Infill:

100%

Notes: Printed with ABS

title: Laser In Use - Light Up Sign

description.text: Ok, so when you've got your safety glasses on and the laser going, and the wife walks in and says, "Oh that's a pretty blue light", you know it's time for a Laser In Use sign. I used a short strip of LEDs that ran on 12 volts that were intended for PC case decoration, but any light source that stays cool should work. I also used as 12 V automotive light up switch, so I knew for sure that the switch was on. Looks cool too-one more thing that lights up. Holder/mount for the switch is included. Also, includes a replacement nut for the light up switch using nut_job.scad from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:193647/#files Setting for nut are: Diameter 16, Height 6, Thread Outer Diameter 13, Thread Step 1. This thingy (minus the nut) is based on the On Air Sign by sxyang119. I simply enlarged the case to the size I wanted, decreased the depth a bit, added some mounting holes, and a hole for the wires to go through and created a new message. After making mine, I noticed that the lettering was a bit too close to the edges of the case. This has been fixed in the file that was uploaded. Also, I printed the message on clear-red PLA from MakerGeeks but realized that it was too transparent. So I masked off the back of the message panel with some dark paint.

I built a 3d printer enclosure and wanted to put in some LED's. I designed this holder to fit in my enclosure and I am pretty happy with how it turned out. It is a very simple design. The LED I used is a 1 watt STAR Led, which I bought from Lighthouse LED's. It is a 5v LED, draws 350mah and requires a 5.6 ohm 1 watt resistor. Use ledcalc.com to confirm your settings if you are doing a similar project.These LED lights get quite hot, so I designed the holder to have a little extra space. Tips:
Run your wiring through the opening in the back. You may want to glue it down with some hot glue. I also glued the edge of my LED to keep it in place. Don't use a lot of glue on the LED, as it will constrict air flow and cause it to overheat. I printed my LED holder out of white PLA, but it has a yellow look to it when the LED's are on. I would recommend using a darker color, like black. Hope you find this useful for your project! I may make a future version that recesses the LED and holds it in place a bit better.

A quick and dirty snap-on calibration meter for the cheap 28BYJ-48 stepper motors. It seems that different batches of these motors have slightly different final gear ratios. Reading online and in my experience, they use anywhere from 4075 - 4100 steps per full rotation of the axle. (in half-step mode, 360 degrees.) This disc has indexes every 10 degrees, and secondary marks at 45 degree increments. There is a little bit of lash in the gearbox, so these motors are not perfect, but by running three motors through 20 full rotations simultaneously, I was able to get a very accurate calibration for my lot of motors. (4096 steps in my case.) I also ran each motor through a series of back and forth movements to test for skipped steps, etc... all returning to zero position at the end. (Stepper Calibration Dance Video)

author: SpaceXAstronaut

description.text: The Microfeeder is a new innovation in hummingbird feeders. It has two special features that make this design superior to others. The first thing you might observe, is that this feeder is not open like most feeders. The bowl of this feeder has a tight fitting lid to keep out wasps and bees, which usually get stuck in normal humming bird feeders. The lid also makes this feeder rain proof and easy to fill. The most important feature of this particular design is the collection box. Most hummingbird feeders will hold sugar water once the birds have drank it down to a certain level. This causes mold and algae to grow rapidly inside the feeder. When liquid is left in a regular feeder for a long time, the mold and algae become very hard to clean off. But the Microfeeder uses the collection box design to drain every drop of liquid from the bowl. Also, the Microfeeder is designed so that even when the bowl is less than halfway full, there is still sugar water near tips of the flowers. This makes it easy for the humming birds to drink. The Microfeeder can be placed in several different locations. It can be nailed to a tree or attached to a window. It can easily be adjusted for use with suction cups or double sided tape. Print one today and enjoy the beauty and grace of hummingbirds! These are the sources I used during the research process of my design: http://homeguides.sfgate.com/color-flowers-attract-hummingbirds-48562.html https://www.reference.com/pets-animals/colors-attract-hummingbirds-723b25547be7c2d4

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

bowl-65% flowers-100% bottom-0% lid-50-65%

Notes: The bottom is printed with three square supports. Use dikes to cut the feeder tube right below the support.

Instructions Please see the attached power point document for step by step assembly instructions. It is located in the thing files. If you cannot view power point documents, please comment me and I can upload a word document of the instructions.

comments.text: This looks so great!! The only question I have is if wasps can get any "nectar" out of the flowers? We have a huge problem with wasps every year, & they are the ONLY reason I can't have a hummingbird feeder. We have the hummingbirds, and we seem to be on a migration route (SO NEAT!!) so I DESPERATELY want a feeder for them. If it can keep the wasps out, I will try to print this off so I am ready in the spring. Thanks
comments.author: Dogsled44

comments.text:
Hi Dogsled44,
Thanks so much for your comment! Yes this humming bird feeder is designed to be wasp proof. When the bowl is full of nectar, the flower stems fill about 3/4 of the way up. The hummingbirds can reach the nectar with their tongue through the tiny holes of the flowers, but wasps cannot. I have problems with wasps too. I have not put this feeder outside yet. I was planning to do so this spring. I would recommend printing the collector box and flower stems with a few shells and only use exterior support. Before you place this out side, fill it with water to test for leaks. If there are any leaks, silicon or hot glue works great to seal it. Also, to work effectively, the feeder needs to remain at least 1/4 of the way full, or it will lose pressure and not fill up the flowers. I hope this helps. I would love to see a picture of your feeder if you decide to make it! Let me know if you have any more questions. Also, since I have not tested this yet, I would love to hear any feedback you have.
Thanks,
Dobielove
comments.author: Dogsled44

description.text:
NOTE - the latch bit has broken on me when printed as is. I'm going to try printing it on its side, that should greatly increase its strength. A little support and touch up work with a file will be required on the round surface. The sled to slide on the Topeak system, and the spring loaded latch to hold things in place. I have a Topeak rack and a bag, but have thought that a plastic ammo box would actually be exactly what I want on the rack. Always waterproof, plenty roomy and I can bolt a big taillight to it and it won't sag and change where it points. Also, Topeak bags are $50 to $100, ammo boxes are $5. There were a couple other sled designs online but none of them were perfect. Mainly they didn't have the little ramp that helps get things on the slide easily.
Also I couldn't find anyone that had replicated the latch to hold things in place.
I'm very happy with how this came out.

Print all the bits. You may not need the backing if you are bolting to something very sturdy, but I was concerned that even with washers they might pull through the $5 ammo box I have.
The latch spring needs to be a compression spring that fits close on a 6mm shaft. I found an expansion spring in the Harbor Freight spring kit #93323, stretched it to make it a compression spring and cut the length I wanted.
To assemble the latch, put the spring over the shaft, compress it a bit, then fit the 2nd half of the latch holder and secure with #6x1/2" sheet metal screws.
Attaching the sleds to your (whatever you are mounting) will be up to you, depending on what you're mounting.
To attach the latch, slide the thing onto the rack, snap the latch over the end bar, then mark the position where the holes should be made in the thing.
The latch is attached to the thing with #8 screws, whatever length you need, and #8 fender washers and #8 nylock nuts.

title: Pitsco Mini Straw Rocket Launcher Accessories

description.text: These parts are for making the Pitsco Mini Straw Rocket Launcher ( http://www.pitsco.com/Mini_Straw_Rocket_Launcher?ap=3602-4096 ) more accurate and repeatable. By snapping on the Angle Indicator, you can more precisely align the angle of the tube before launching the straw rockets. Using the numbered stopper allows you to pull the plunger back to a very repeatable distance so the kids get better data when they are launching their rockets. Unfortunately, since I made these for my sons' class months ago, I don't have any pictures of them on the launcher. If you find out your kids' teacher is planning on using this model rocket launcher, you could make them very happy with a couple sets of these.
Step 1 Get the Pitsco Mini Rocket Launcher. Print these parts for you if you are the teacher, or your kids' teacher.
Step 2 Follow along with whatever instruction plan came with the Pitsco Mini Rocket Launcher kit because this is just to help improve the chances of getting repeatable data for the kids to analyze.

description.text: TG Simon is a simple memory game, I have uploaded the design so you could have it ready for Christmas, the instructions are a work in progress however I have uploaded all the files you will need, it has a arduino Uno at its heart, and is a fully self contained and functional game...... enjoy.

** These Instructions are a work in progress, check the picture if you get stuck. Non printed parts list. 2 x 5mm red LED's all around 3volt
2 x 5mm blue LED's
2 x 5mm green LED's
2 x 5mm yellow LED's
4 x 220 Ohm resistors for LEDs
7 x 6mm square momentary switches - Got 100 on ebay for about $4.00
I used about 2m of cat 5 cable chopped up for connections.
1 x 9v battery clip
1 x 9v battery
8 x 3mm nut and bold about 10 to 15mm long
about 10 screws to hold in Arduino and screw the whole thing together - you will need to cut these to length as you go, I just used my pliers.
1 x length of heat shrink to protect and strengthen all soldered connections.
1 x strip Header Terminal Strip ( about $1.00) at jaycar
1 x Miniature DPDT Panel Mount Switch Size 35(L) x 13(W)mm. Actuator height 6mm.Mounting holes 28mm apart.3mm diameter holes for screws. CAT. NO. SS0821 I got this one from Jaycar.
1 x Arduino UNO R3
1 x Speaker OBO -1205A (-D5+342) piezo if using a 8 Ohm speaker instead make sure you connect a 100 Ohm resistor in series with it.
super glue. Mini Amplifier for speaker / piezo - see circuit diagram
1 x 1M Ohm resistor
1 x 150k resistor
1 x BC547NPN transistor
1 x 10 uf electrolytic Capacitor I have designed all the parts to print without support, I recommend at least 3 shells and some parts may need light trimming as some filament will run a little, but that should be in areas you can't see. Printed Parts
4 x Paddle (large) buttons, 1 of each colour.
4 x sets of 2 Paddle button brackets whatever colour they cant be seen.
3 x Control Buttons 2 x yellow, 1 x red or mix it up.
1 x Top - Black
1 x Button support, same colour as Top
1 x Base - Black
1 x Battery Cover - Black
1 x Power switch
8 x LED support brackets - clear to opaque All switches are run from the ground not the +5V. Anybody who like to right instructions your help would be appreciated. I have uploaded the code for the arduino, the tune library came pre installed in my assembler but I uploaded it just in case. You can learn all about adding library's on the arduino website. I have uploaded a file with thepinout of the arduino in case anyone gets stuck. Ok here are the basic assembly instructions. Turn the top upside down and place in the 3 control buttons, red for start.
Place in the 4 Paddle buttons - see picture.
Place in all 8 paddle support brackets and bolt them into place, make sure the bolts aren't sticking up or the next layer wont sit flat.
Cut the leads on the LED's about 5mm long, wire them in parallel, 2 per paddle with a extra negative wire poking out about 70mm near one corner of the paddle (this will connect to the switches later to keep things neat) and glue them into the LED support brackets leave about 150mm on the +ve lead to connect a 220 Ohm resistor(now) and then to the arduino later, use heat shrink as you go, even cover the resistor to keep it neat.
* The red paddle is above the battery compartment, make sure all the wires are close to the corner, you can use the button support to double check.
Glue the LED's into the paddle buttons, try not to get glue on the paddle button brackets.
  • Clean out any screw holes that are blocked.
  • Pre wire all the buttons, from one side leave about 150mm of lead to connect to the arduino later, from the other side connect them all together this will be the -ve or ground wire then from one of the middle switches run an extra -ve about 150mm long to connect to the arduing gnd later, on each of the 4 outside switches leave enough wire (about 50mm) to go the the -ve from the LEDs. I found wiring one switch, gluing it into place then wiring the next was the easiest. Try placing one of the switches in place and putting the button support into place and pressing on the paddle button to get a good feel for where the switch need to be glued, they should sit on the bottom of the slope. - don't forget the heat shrink.
    Using the centre mounting screw holes mount the button support to the top.
    Make up the amplifier - see the attached circuit diagram - leave the leads long enough to put it out of the road for when you put the covers on.
    Break up the Header Terminal Strip into 3 pieces. 2 pins for the power in, 8 pins for terminals 0-7 and 7 pins for terminals 8-13.
    Follow the attached pin out document for what connections go where - don't forget the heat shrink. - see picture.
    Feed the wires from the 9v battery clip from outside in and connect +ve to switch then from switch as shown on the pin out document (+ vin and - GND)
    Upload arduino sketch - to the arduino you wont be able to plug it into the PC after you have mounted it.
    Cut screws to length and mount the arduino - I only used 2 screws.
    Glue switch and piezo into place.
    Plug in the remainder header pins and screw on the cover - loosely, to tight and the paddle buttons will jam and you wont be able to play !.
    Insert battery.
    *Insert battery cover and screw into place.
    • *This is the rough draft of the instructions - let me know If I missed anything or misspelled anything, ENJOY !! GAMEPLAY.
    When TG SIMON starts and after every game ends it will enter menu mode and the following options become available:- START will start a game on game 2 (14 turns).
    LAST will play last game if more than one button was pressed.
    BEST will play the longest game.
  • press green then START for game 1 (8 turns).
  • press red then START for game 2 (14 turns) ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ default.
  • press yellow then START for game 3 (20 turns).
  • press blue then START for game 4 (31 turns).
  • hold green and red - mute
  • hold green and blue - unmute
    • **When selecting a game it will flash that colour to confirm the game selected after you press the START button.

title: Aluminum angle iron for Y-axis support

description.text:
Update 2-5-17
noticed I was still having bed leveling issues, I replaced the y-carriage with a new one made out of Aluminum and 3mm thick ( https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01MUAMRN7/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 ) instead of the 1mm thick steel plate that comes on the machine - What a Difference that made. Picture shows the difference of the thickness of the 2 plates vs the heating bed
According to my dial gage ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2040422 ) the bed is now level within .010 mm (10 microns)

I noticed on my Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2.1 that my plate was not staying flat when trying to get the bed to level with the nozzle at all points.
Upon looking closer, it appeared that the bed the Y-axis bearings are mounted to, was flexing and this was causing 2 opposite corners to either be way too loose or too tight when screwing down the springs, due to the flexing.
Went to the hardware store and got a piece of 1/2 x 3/4 inch Aluminum angle iron (only size there that would fit - would have preferred 1/4 x 1/2 inch)
Drilled out 2 holes on each end on the 3/4 flat side, and mounted the angle iron between the Y-axis carriage plate and the springs, and releveled the bed.

What a difference it made.

All 4 corners came into acceptable tolerances and were not ratcheted down all the way. - Good thing too because at the back of the heated bed the wires are getting pinched a bit - not a good thing!! Adjustments will have to be made there.
there is enough material left over to run the angle iron down the sides as well, but there might not be a need for it now.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter
1/2 " x 1/2 " angle iron - a 3 foot piece will cover all 4 sides

description.text:
Bosch 18v lithium battery to Ryobi one plus tool adapter.

photographed model is prototype, and current version has the red part moved back 4mm.

you may want to cover up the exposed metal part with epoxy etc, to prevent accidental short.

comments.text:
I love your work, it seems that you specialised on making battery adapters for power tools.
Could I perhaps persuade you to concider making a similar adapter for bosch 18V battery but with adapter for Dewalt tools?
comments.author: Nklint

comments.text: I don't have a Bosch battery, but I appreciate you making and sharing this all the same! Thanks for being awesome!
